sites.name: Cathédrale Notre-Dame de Reims
sites.description: This magnificent Gothic cathedral, built between 1211-1345, is one of France's most important religious buildings and the traditional site of French royal coronations. With its stunning façade featuring over 2,300 statues, magnificent stained glass windows by Marc Chagall, and impressive flying buttresses, it's a masterpiece of medieval architecture and a UNESCO World Heritage site.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. Summer brings long daylight hours for admiring the façade. Spring and autumn offer pleasant weather for exploration. Winter visits are quieter with beautiful light through stained glass.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required for general visits. Guided tours available in multiple languages. Check schedule for special events and organ concerts.

sites.name: Palais du Tau
sites.description: This former archbishop's palace, adjacent to the cathedral, houses the Musée de l'Œuvre and displays the cathedral's treasury, coronation regalia, and architectural fragments. The building itself is a masterpiece of medieval and classical architecture, showcasing the wealth and power of the Reims archbishops.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with climate control. Special exhibitions rotate seasonally. Less crowded on weekday mornings.
sites.booking_tips: Advance booking recommended during peak season. Audio guides available in multiple languages. Combined tickets available with the cathedral.

sites.name: Basilique Saint-Remi
sites.description: This impressive Romanesque basilica, built in the 11th century, houses the relics of Saint Remi who baptized Clovis, the first Christian king of France. The church features beautiful Romanesque architecture, medieval frescoes, and a peaceful atmosphere that contrasts with the grandeur of the cathedral.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful lighting in afternoon hours. Special religious services during important feast days. Organ concerts occasionally held.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Respect quiet during services. Check schedule for special events and concerts.

sites.name: Musée Saint-Remi
sites.description: Housed in the former abbey buildings adjacent to the basilica, this museum showcases Reims' rich history from prehistoric times through the modern era. The collection includes archaeological finds, medieval artifacts, and exhibits on the city's role in French history and the Champagne region.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with climate control. Special exhibitions rotate seasonally. Less crowded on weekday afternoons.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required for general admission. Audio guides available in French and English. Combined tickets available with other museums.

sites.name: Place Drouet d'Erlon
sites.description: This lively square in the heart of Reims is lined with cafés, restaurants, and shops, making it the perfect place to experience the city's vibrant atmosphere. The square features beautiful fountains and is particularly atmospheric in the evening when locals gather for drinks and dining.
sites.seasonal_notes: Lively throughout the year. Summer brings outdoor dining and street performers. The square is beautifully decorated during Christmas season.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Many restaurants offer outdoor seating in good weather. Popular spot for people-watching and Champagne tasting.

sites.name: Porte de Mars
sites.description: This impressive Roman triumphal arch, built in the 3rd century AD, is the largest surviving Roman arch in the world. Standing 33 meters high, it features elaborate carvings depicting Roman mythology and military victories, showcasing Reims' ancient heritage as the Roman city of Durocortorum.
sites.seasonal_notes: Visible year-round. Best photographed in morning light. The surrounding area is particularly pleasant in spring and autumn.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free to view from the street. Located near the train station and easily accessible.

sites.name: Champagne Houses
sites.description: Reims is the capital of Champagne, and visiting the famous champagne houses is a must. Companies like Veuve Clicquot, Taittinger, and Pommery offer tours of their historic cellars, some dating back to Roman times, where you can learn about the champagne-making process and enjoy tastings.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with climate-controlled cellars. Summer is peak tourist season. Winter offers intimate experiences with fewer crowds.
sites.booking_tips: Advance booking essential for all champagne house tours. Tours available in multiple languages. Some houses require reservations weeks in advance.

sites.name: Musée de la Reddition
sites.description: This museum is located in the building where Germany surrendered to the Allies on May 7, 1945, ending World War II in Europe. The museum preserves the original room where the surrender was signed and displays artifacts, documents, and exhibits related to this historic event.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round except Mondays. Air conditioned in summer. Special exhibitions related to World War II history.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Audio guides available in multiple languages. Allow time for the emotional impact of the historic surrender room.

sites.name: Place Royale
sites.description: This elegant square, designed in the 18th century, features a statue of Louis XV and is surrounded by beautiful classical buildings. The square exemplifies the architectural elegance of Reims and provides a perfect setting for photography and people-watching.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful year-round. Summer brings outdoor café culture. Winter offers cozy indoor experiences. The square is particularly atmospheric in the evening.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Best explored on foot. Many cafés offer outdoor seating in good weather.

sites.name: Cryptoportique
sites.description: This underground Roman gallery, built in the 3rd century AD, was likely used for storage and commerce in ancient Reims. The well-preserved structure provides insight into Roman urban planning and engineering, showcasing the city's ancient heritage beneath the modern streets.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with climate control. Underground location makes it comfortable in all seasons. Guided tours available.
sites.booking_tips: Advance booking recommended for guided tours. Audio guides available. Located near the cathedral.

sites.name: Quartier des Halles
sites.description: This charming historic district features narrow medieval streets, traditional shops, and authentic local atmosphere. The area is known for its traditional crafts, local boutiques, and historic architecture that provides a contrast to the grand religious buildings and shows Reims' medieval heritage.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful year-round. Summer brings outdoor café culture. Winter offers cozy indoor shopping experiences. The district is particularly atmospheric in the evening.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Best explored on foot. Many shops close on Sundays and Monday mornings.

sites.name: Parc de la Patte d'Oie
sites.description: This large public park on the outskirts of Reims offers walking trails, picnic areas, and beautiful views of the city and surrounding Champagne countryside. The park is popular with locals for outdoor activities and provides a peaceful escape from the busy city center.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful in spring with blossoming trees. Summer offers shade and cooler temperatures. Autumn brings beautiful foliage colors. Winter visits are peaceful but weather-dependent.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free access at all times. Parking available. Popular for jogging and cycling.

sites.name: Musée des Beaux-Arts
sites.description: This museum, housed in a beautiful 18th-century building, showcases a collection of fine art from the 16th to 20th centuries. The collection includes works by French and European artists, with particular emphasis on the art of the Champagne region and the city's cultural heritage.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round except Tuesdays. Air conditioned in summer. Special exhibitions rotate seasonally.
sites.booking_tips: No advance booking required. Free guided tours available on weekends. Audio guides available in French and English.

sites.name: Chapelle Foujita
sites.description: This unique chapel, designed and decorated by the Japanese-French artist Léonard Foujita in 1966, features beautiful frescoes and stained glass windows. The chapel combines traditional Christian iconography with Japanese artistic influences, creating a unique cultural fusion.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round for visitors. Beautiful lighting in morning hours. The chapel is particularly atmospheric during quiet periods.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Respect quiet during services. Check schedule for special events and cultural programs.

sites.name: Place du Forum
sites.description: This charming square in the old town features historic buildings and is surrounded by traditional cafés and restaurants. The square is a perfect place to experience the authentic atmosphere of Reims and enjoy a coffee or glass of champagne while watching local life unfold.
sites.seasonal_notes: Lively throughout the year. Summer brings outdoor dining and street life. Winter offers cozy indoor café experiences. The square is particularly atmospheric in the evening.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Many cafés offer outdoor seating in good weather. Popular spot for people-watching and photography.

sites.name: Canal de l'Aisne à la Marne
sites.description: This historic canal, built in the 19th century, connects the Aisne and Marne rivers and passes through the Champagne region. The canal is lined with walking paths and offers a peaceful route for exploring the outskirts of Reims. It's particularly beautiful in the evening when illuminated.
sites.seasonal_notes: Beautiful year-round. Spring brings fresh greenery along the banks. Summer evenings feature pleasant walks and cooling breezes. Autumn offers beautiful foliage colors.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Free access at all times. Popular for evening strolls and photography.
